content.description: Tricky start to a highish first bolt. A little more business passing bolt 3 and then a cruise to the top. You may want to bring some slings to extend the anchor to reduce drag setting a top rope.
content.protection: 6 bolts to anchors with lowering biners.
content.location: First route past the break in the wall after Bananamobile and Future Primitive. The base of the route is on a slightly elevated scree pile, as opposed the packed dirt below the routes to the left. As most climbs on this wall, a TR can be set from the top, accessed by the north or south ends of the cliff band.

content.description: Crux is at the 2nd to 3rd bolt. It is easier for taller people. This has a bouldery start, a delicate middle section, and an easy finish.
content.protection: Bolted
content.location: To the right of Pie Rats Ahoy. Start on left side of boulder/ledge.

content.description: Short boulder problem followed by much easier climbing above
content.protection: 4 bolts and chain anchors with lowering biners
content.location: On the huecoed column of rock just before a break in the overall rock formation where the trail takes a slight jog. Look for a large flat boulder at the base of this route.

content.description: Straightforward climbing with plenty of holds and rests, minor crux 2/3 of the way up.
content.protection: 4 bolts with steel lowering biners on the anchors
content.location: This route is located about 1/3 of the way along the base of the entire wall where the trail goes through a short jog and the rock become less monolithic. Look for two gigantic blocks sitting on a ledge, this route is just right of these blocks.

climbs.name: Scott Ain't Got Time For That

content.description: This is a fun juggy sport route.  It reminds one of an indoor sport climb.  The crux is above the second bolt.  Keep climbing and the holds will appear.
content.protection: Bolts to anchors
content.location:
The route is to the right of a black streak. 

  Rap the route.

climbs.name: Rudolf von Flugel Loops the Loops

content.description: Consistent 5.7 climbing, with a crux move just after the third bolt. The anchors of this route also make for an excellent place to practice rappelling due to a comfortable stance on a ledge below the anchors.
content.protection: 6 bolts + anchors with quick links on hangers with lowering biners
content.location: Far left side as you face the wall of the first main area. There are now three bolted routes to the left of this route, two were added 4/10/2018 and one 1/20/2019 making this the fourth bolted line you come to when you enter the area. Look for a black streak to the left of this route.

content.description: The crux is above the second bolt where there is a long reach to the left.  The climb becomes easier as one climbs higher.
content.protection: Bolts to anchors at the top.
content.location:
The climb starts off a boulder to the right of Wonder Showzen. 

  Rap the route.

climbs.name: Officer Flossie
climbs.fa: J Laing, L Robinson, and D Turner

content.description: Interesting crux about a quarter of the way up with a gaston and side pull. The rest is typical low angle slab climbing.
content.protection: 5 bolts and chain anchors with lowering biners. Can be top roped easily.
content.location: Look for the gaping undercling/sidepull half way up. This route is now the fifth bolted route from the entrance after two routes were added to the short wall on the far left side, Hehaw Donkey and Babykins 4/10/2018, and another was added to the tall part of the wall, Goldbug 1/20/2019.

content.description: Low angle climbing, with ledges following a crack that runs the length of the route. Shares an anchor with Goldbug, the bolted sport route to the right of it.
content.protection: small, medium and large pro, there are placements almost everywhere along this route.
content.location: This route is the crack just to the left of Goldbug. It is towards the far left side of Scarry Wall. As you walk into Scarry Wall from the trail, look for a 3' wide vertical black streak just after the wall increases in height. This route is to the left of the black streak.

content.description: Slab climbing with great holds
content.protection: 5 bolts and chain anchor with lowering biners
content.location: As one is walking along the base of Scarry Wall with the wall on your left, this route is just before the first jog in the trail where the cliff becomes low angle and broken up. Look for a blocky jumbled crack to it's left (Mr. Fixit).

climbs.name: Mr. Fixit (Breaks Santa's Sleigh)
climbs.fa: J Laing, L Robinson, and D Turner

content.description: A sequence of three or four low grade dihedral boulder problems with large rest ledges between.
content.protection: small to medium cams to 1.5" and nuts. Ring anchors in the alcove at the top. Can easily be toproped.
content.location: In the jumbled crack just left of Mr. Gronkle's Giveaway. Towards the far right side of the first formation you come to from the access trail.

climbs.name: More Fun Than Three Monkeys in a Bananamobile

content.description: Quality climbing with interesting moves. Thinner face climbing below, followed by hand jams and stemming, with slab climbing at the top. Be careful about rope management around the fourth bolt, when transitioning across the large cracks. Keep your right foot from being on the wrong side of the rope as you make the transition to the upper face. The left leaning crack at the bottom can also be led on gear to then join the bolted route for the top.
content.protection: 6 bolts and chain anchors with lowering biners
content.location: In the crack system with dark colored rock. There is a left leaning crack that runs along the first 15 feet of this route and ends where the climbing takes to the face above the crack.

content.description: Easier for taller people and those that wander left and right of the bolt line. Although blank looking from the ground, the middle section has some nice pockets and a couple crimper flakes that provide some nice holds by the third bolt.
content.protection: 3 bolts to chain anchors with lowering biners
content.location: Squeezed between BVC on the left and Babooby on the right. Currently the second route from the right most end of all of Scarry Wall. Look for a small bush/tree mid way up the wall under which you will find the anchors of Mistress Mouse.

climbs.name: Lowly Worm's Applecopter Express
climbs.fa: V Turner, J Laing, and D Turner

content.description: There are lots of variations one can take for this line. Staying left at the bottom and the top is harder (5.8) while the easier lines are on the right side. The spacing between bolts 3 and 4 is long, but the moves are easy with big holds. The crux is at the fourth bolt.
content.protection: 5 bolts and chain anchors with lowering biners

climbs.name: Kitty Loves Pickles
climbs.fa: L Robinson, D Turner, and J Laing

content.description: Consistent climbing through up a crack of widely varying widths, although crack climbing technique is not really necessary at any point on this route.
content.protection: A little bit of everything small nuts, medium cams. A large cam (BD#6) comes in handy for a large offwidth section half way up. Bolted anchor directly above the ledge at the top.
content.location: Just to the right of Bear Hugging Big Hilda which is in the middle section of climbing on Scarry Wall. From the access trail, after passing the first section of bolted slab climbs the trail starts to wind a bit and go up a small rise. Big Hilda can be identified because it looks like a giant left-leaning "v" formed by two cracks. Kittle Loves Pickles is the right crack of this "v".

content.description: Fun climbing, perfect for kids or a first lead. Note: Consensus grade among four-year-olds is 5.17
content.protection: 6 bolts and chain anchors with lowering biners
content.location: In the jumble half way between the right side of the first slab as you face the wall and Bear Hugging Big Hilda.

climbs.name: Heehaw Donkey
climbs.fa: E Turner, A Turner, D Turner and G Turner

content.description: Starts with some tricky moves through a couple large scoops. Then fairly straightforward 5.6 slab climbing above.
content.protection: 4 bolts to 2 bolt anchor with rings and lowering biners
content.location: The first route one comes to from the approach trail, right at the bottom of the rock steps coming down

content.description: Fun climbing, more thought-provoking than it looks from the ground. One can either start directly in front of the subtle bulge or ease into the route from the right. The crux is after the second bolt on thin hand holds, but good feet.
content.protection: 4 bolts to anchor with steel lowering biners
content.location: As you enter Scarry Wall from the trail, look for the black streak that runs vertically just to the right of a hand width crack. This is Goldbug.

content.description: The route has an easy first clip and then crux right stepping moves above the first bolt going to the second. Continue up and large huecos are found climbing over the small bulge.
content.protection: Bolts to a two-bolt anchor. Rap from anchors at the top.
content.location: The route starts on a flatter area just a bit right of More Fun Than Three Monkeys in a Bananamobile

content.description: Lean across from the large rock to clip the first bolt. Fun route with some interesting moves.
content.protection: Bolted
content.location: Start about 10 ft to the right of Terrible Dragon.

content.description: Fun climbing on big holds and ledges to a slightly tricky slab section 3/4 of the way up
content.protection: 5 bolts, 2 bolt anchor with lowering biners
content.location: Roughly in the center of Scarry Wall, just past the jog in the trail, between Huckle Cat and Bear Higging Big Hilda. Look for a rather isolated column of rock with horizontal breaks and ledges.

climbs.name: Dingo Dog
climbs.fa: J Laing, L Robinson, and D Turner

content.description: One of the easier lines in the first section of climbing. Consistent low angle slab movement.
content.protection: 5 bolts with chain anchors and lowering biners
content.location: This route is just to the left of a subtle gully with large grasses growing near the top.

content.description: Until you figure out the beta for this route you might hate it, or be frustrated by it, but once you figure it out, it will likely become one of your favorites at Scarry Wall. It's got a bit of everything packed into a short boulder problem (underclings, slopers, crimps, two knee bars, and a committing finish to the bulge).
content.protection: 4 bolts, anchor has steel lowering biners
content.location: Starts square in the middle of the big boulder at the base of the farthest right wall at Scarry Wall. Look for the prominent roof created by large bulge in the rock, with light tan rock underneath.

content.description: Consistently fun climbing with great protection. This route makes for an excellent first lead.
content.protection: 6 bolts and ring anchors with lowering biners
content.location: Look for the giant left-leaning "v" which forms an arete, this is Bear Higgin Big Hilda (the arete) and Kity Loves Pickles (trad, the crack on the right of the "v"). Beverly Baboon is the next bolted line to the climber's right. It starts on a slab and heads up to a left leaning system of cracks.

content.description:
There is a great hold in the crack to the left of the first bolt that is great for clipping the high first bolt. Taking the direct line up the front of the blunt arête makes for harder climbing than the right face of the arête. The crux is near the second bolt. 

  This route, as well as the next three can be accessed from the top by scrambling (4th class) behind the large boulder pile above Big Hilda, but its not as easy to set up top ropes on these as it is for the routes to the left as you face the wall. One should probably set up a rappel anchor to do this and exercise caution.
content.protection: 4 bolts and chain anchors with lowering biners
content.location: On the arête between the two major slab formations.

climbs.name: Baron Von Crow
climbs.fa: J Laing, L Robinson, and D Turner

content.description: Jugs to gain the first ledge then an engaging, reachy sidepull gets you established above the first bump out. Easier climbing past this crux with large holds. Low-angle runout slab to the top.
content.protection: 6 bolts to chain anchor with rings and lowering biners almost at the top of the formation (20' feet taller than Scott AGTT to the left or Babooby to the right). The anchors were placed high up to make top roping easy to access. One can lead this route on gear as well using small to medium cams and stoppers to protect the crack.
content.location: The second to last bolted climb along the access trail towards the far right side of the right section of climbing at Scarry Wall. Look for a seam that runs 5 or 10 feet left of a small tree sticking out of a ledge.

climbs.name: Babykins
climbs.fa: A Turner, E Turner, D Turner, and G Turner

content.description:
Begin in the large left leaning gap and climb to the top of a small ledge about eight feet up. The first bolt can be reached from the top of the ledge. The grade varies depending on how far up the gap one continues. Climbing straight up is more challenging. 

  Caution: Stay away from the large boulders perched on the ledge below the anchors to the left of Babykins. They're not on the route, but when lowering, the climber passes next to them.
content.protection: four bolts and two bolt anchor with quick links and lowering biners
content.location: Look for a high first bolt above the large left-leaning gap. From the bottom of the rock stairs entering Scarry Wall, this route is only a couple paces away. Babykins and Heehaw Donkey are on a shorter wall on the far left side of the first section of climbing at Scarry Wall.

climbs.name: Babooby
climbs.fa: J Laing, L Robinson, D Turner, Vaino Kodas, and doni

content.description: V0 boulder problem to get established on the ledge above the first bolt, then an interesting move to reach the large horizontal flake jug, to an easier finish. A good warm up if you're gearing up for the sporty climbs in the right most section of Scarry Wall
content.protection: three bolts, chain anchors with lowering biners. The second bolt looks high from the ground, but it's no sweat to clip once on the ledge. The second bolt needs to be high to protect against falling on the ledge for the mid crux.
content.location: Currently the furthest route to the right of all the climbing at Scarry Wall where the height of the wall begins to diminish. Follow the access trail until you start to squeeze through bushes and trees. Look for a small tree sticking out at the top of the route.

content.description: Another fun climb with great holds. Good footwork will get you through the crux between the first and second bolt.
content.protection: 5 bolts and chain anchors with lowering biners
content.location: Look for a high first bolt with a 6 foot tall subtle scoop above the first bolt. This route is a few feet before reaching a large, split-in-half boulder as one walks along the base of the cliff. The route above the boulder is Snozzle.

content.description:
Scarry Wall (a.k.a. Hidden Wall, a.k.a. Gateway Wall) [Topo .pdf] consists of a handful of easy sport and trad slab routes. The rock quality is generally stable. A lot of route cleaning has been done, but caution should be exercised when accessing top anchors as to not drop loose rock on people below. This crag is perfect for the aspiring lead climber as it has several routes grade 5.9 and under, and it's well protected. The base of the climbing is flat, shaded by bushes, and makes a great place for kids and dogs to run around.Don't be fooled by the crag's name, which is in honor of the children's book author Richard Scarry. Many of the route are named after his characters. This wall is anything but scary.Abridged History (thanks to Bob Broilo): Most of these lines were done on natural pro in the 90's by climbers such as Andy Mayer or Talon Newton, and more recently, Victor Alvidrez and Bob Broilo. On one of them (named "Sangre de Andy" for the blood stain that marked the bottom for years) Andy Mayer almost died when a hold broke sending him crashing 40' feet down the rock, stopping 6-8 feet from the ground! Andy returned later to send the line. Some of these routes have also been bouldered (boldly) or soloed. Since the specifics of much of this history has been lost, the FAs are listed as those who established permanent anchors on the routes with full recognition that all of these lines have been done many times before.The initial development involved three bolted sport lines installed on the far right side of the crag, established by Scott Roberts, Bob Broilo, Katie Sauer, and Jason Hebert. John Laing and Dan Turner bolted several more in the spring of 2015, followed by a handful of additions by Vaino Kodas and doni. Six more routes were added in various spots among the crag by Lin Robinson, John Laing and Dan Turner in the Winter of 2017.There is a V3+ traverse called Sangre de Lizard that traverses all the major rock outcrops. Bring water and comfy shoes...

Scarry Wall Topo

Routes as viewed from above
